description:
Age of Monarchs is a multiplayer card-driven grand strategy game simulating the three centuries of the Modern Age, from Columbus' discovery of America in 1492 to the fall of the Bastille in 1789. Players represent the highest rungs of European monarchy, assuming the leadership of a major European Power, and struggling to achieve global supremacy over the world in the Age of Absolutism. Being an absolute monarch, each player must manage every kind of question: economic, political, diplomacy, trade, world wide exploration, colonization, religion and warfare.

Age of Monarchs is designed to offer an accurate and detailed historical context, supported by more than 160 strategy cards that simulate the most outstanding historical events and force players to face constantly the toughest challenges that occurred during the three centuries covered by the game timeline.

The game offers a wide set of short scenarios and a Grand Campaign 1492-1789, spanning 20 turns, that put the most powerful European nations into a never-ending struggle for world domination.

The complete list of Scenarios:

• 1492-1559 Age of Exploration
• 1560-1618 Wars of Religion
• 1619-1667 Thirty Years War
• 1668-1730 Age of Absolutism
• 1698-1789 Wars of Supremacy

In Age of Monarchs players take the role of the absolute monarch of a Major Power. Monarchs are represented by Strategy Cards that reproduce historical characters (plus some generic ones), each with special abilities that affect game rules. The game manages also the aging of monarchs, and their replacement by new monarchs, crowned after their predecessor is dead, thus allowing players to handle a line of succession in the monarchy of their Powers.

Strategy Cards are the core of the game. They provide Command Points that allow players to perform all Game Actions, but they also introduce the most outstanding historical events of the Modern Age, such as the Protestant Reformation, the Wars of Religion, the birth of Holland (United Provinces), the Eighty Years war with Spain, the rise and decline of the Portuguese and Spanish colonial empires, the Thirty Years War, the rush of the Russian Empire to Siberia, the Great Northern Wars, the growth of the Ottoman Empire, the wars with Christianity, the Wars of Succession, the birth of the USA, and many more.

Game Actions allow players to perform activities in all spheres. To summarize a few:

Warfare: the game has a light military system. Players can rapidly move or redeploy forces, engage land battles, resolve sieges and naval combats. Supply mechanics are very simple. Leaders play a fundamental role in game-play, either as Generals, Admirals or Conquistadors.
Diplomacy: many Minor Nations are present in the game. All players can influence these Minors to get Alliances and Vassals, benefiting from their military support during conflicts.
Exploration, Colonization and Trade: the game recreates the race of the Powers to build Colonial Empires all over the world. New colonies bring income from the exploitation of exotic resources and gold. The game allows players to affect the prices of exotic goods in order to speculate on price fluctuations as well. Gold can have a strong impact on the European economy due to Inflation!
Economy: players must pay attention to the budget of their Powers. At the end of each turn, players perform some short and rapid calculations to determine the budget balance of their Monarchies, based on revenues (taxes, colonial incomes, trade) and costs (maintenance of forces). The game has also the concept of Prosperity, measuring the richness of each Power, strongly affected by the length and outcome of wars.

Game overview:

• Complexity: 6 / 10
• Game length: 5+ hours
• Number of players: 3-6
• Time scale: about 10 years per turn
• Solitaire suitability: low

In Bluff im Zoo, the players are returning from the zoo and talking about who's seen the biggest and most animals — but not everyone is telling the truth. On a turn, a player can do one of the following:


     Play a card face down on a pile in the middle of all players and claim to have seen a certain number of one of five kinds of animal; this number must be either higher than any previously claimed number or the same number of a larger animal.
     Not play a card and make a claim.
     Doubt the previous player's claim.


When a player doubts an opponent, all cards are revealed. If there are at least the number of animals that the previous player claimed, the doubter takes all the cards (which are worth negative points); if not, the person who made the claim collects them. But beware as the deck contains special cards — e.g., jokers that count as any animal and cards that reduce the number of animals seen — so no one can ever be sure which animals await.

The first player to collect thirty cards loses and ends the game, then the player with the fewest cards wins.

Coal Baron – or Glück Auf in German, after a greeting German miners use when wishing one another luck – has players sending miners underground to dig tunnels and acquire coal, which comes in four levels of quality and is used to fulfill contracts.

The game lasts three rounds, and in each round players take turns placing their workers on action spaces; you can place on a space occupied by another player, but you need to place additional workers in order to do so. Each player has an individual elevator shaft, and will need to use workers to extract coal and bring it to the surface, while also competing for contracts and scrounging for cash in order to do everything else that needs to be done!

Send out the scouts! Position the Flagship in tactical orbit! And reconfigure that Battlestation into something new! Your fleet of loyal ships, powered by the might of quantum  probability itself, carries your empire to the far-flung stars. How will history remember you? As a ravenous destroyer? A clever tactician? A dauntless explorer? Command your armada, construct world-shattering technologies, and rally the remnants of humanity for a final confrontation.

In Quantum, each player is a fleet commander from one of the four factions of humanity, struggling to conquer a sector of space. Every die is a starship, with the value of the die determining the movement of the ship, but also its combat power - with low numbers more powerful. So a [ 6 ] is a quick but fragile Scout and a [ 1 ] is a slow but mighty Battlestation.

Each type of ship also has a special power that can be used once per turn: Destroyers can warp space to swap places with other dice and Flagships can transport other ships. These powers can be used in combination for devastating effects. You're not stuck with your starting ships, however: using Quantum technology, you can spend actions to transform (re-roll) your ships. Randomness plays a role in the game, but only when you want: Quantum is very much a strategy game.

You win by constructing Quantum Cubes - massive planetary energy extractors. Each time you build a new one, you can expand your fleet, earn a new permanent ability, or take a one-time special move. The board itself is made out of modular tiles, and you can play on one of the 30 layouts that come with the game or design your own. The ship powers, player abilities, and board designs combine to create a limitless set of possibilities for how to play and strategies for how to win.

With elegant mechanics, an infinity of scenarios, and easy-to-learn rules that lead to deep gameplay, Quantum is a one-of-a-kind game of space combat, strategy and colonization that will satisfy both hard-core and casual players.

Quantum won the 2012 Game Design Award at the IndieCade Festival of Independent Games, as a prototype game with the title Armada d6.

Amid the Ashes is a post-apocalyptic survival game in which you must ensure the supremacy of your faction by dominating what few resources are left amid the wasteland of an obliterated city. You must explore the ruins, survive radioactive fallout, fight mutants and rival factions, all in a bid to secure the last scraps of fuel, ammunition and clean water. (This is a build-it-yourself game. You must print the PDF and cut out the components to play)

It used a tile system where the tiles are revealed through exploration, each one containing a variety of buildings, environments and resources that will aid the player in achieving victory.

Throne Maker is an express style dice game inspired by Kingdom Builder in which players take it in turns over a series of rounds to roll, match and arrange dice in order to score.  The player with the highest score at the end of the final round wins the game.

Each round the criteria for scoring changes as the Throne Makers with influence  are randomly rolled.  Special ability tokens and the opportunity to influence the next player's score all feature in game play.

This game was created as an entry in the 2013 PnP Express/In-a-tin competition and therefore the initial version is designed to be as compact and portable as possible.

Fields of War MG is a game in which each player battle and an attempt to kill all there opponents units or to take their castle. To start the game each player has a army 18 units of there race starting races(Elf, Human and Ork more to come!). Each turn players will roll for points, these will then be use to place mats use ability and move units.

Each race has a unique ability that they will use alongside there side mat (up to 15 may be chosen)

This is a light weight card game for up to six players, ages 5 and up.  The goal is to keep the chain of links (cards) going.  The deck is made of a count up/count down card, four different colored links numbering 1-12 in each color, and flip cards.  The first person to play all their cards wins the game.

There are five short rules for the game.  
1) Never play a card that has the same color as the top card in the chain.  
2) If Count Up is facing up, the value of your card must be higher than the top card of the chain, unless you play a Flip card.  Likewise, if Count Down is facing up, the value of your card must be smaller than the top card of the chain, unless you play a Flip.  
3) The three ways to flip the Count Down / Count Up card is to play a 1, play a 12, or play a flip.  If you play a 1 this flips the Count Down card to Count Up.  Play a 12 and the Count Up card to Count Down.  If you play a Flip, the Count Up / Count Down card to the opposite side.  
4) When a Flip is played, the color of the Flip is what is used for Rule #1, and the value of the card under the Flip is the value you use for Rule #2 depending on what side the Count Up / Count Down is face up.  
5)  If you can not play a card, draw one from the draw pile.  If you can play the card drawn, do so, if not play passes to the next person.  If there are no more cards to draw from shuffle all but the last two cards of the chain up and make them the draw deck.

Menagerie highlights the diverse range of New Zealand's wildlife and some of the threats to the survival of these animals. You are in control of a nature reserve, with three habitat types (High Country, Forest and Coastal) which will be filled with breeding populations of suitable animals. Each turn a player draws a card and must either play animals into their habitats or discard a card. The game ends once a player has been able to play all the cards from their hands.

With the introduction of Threat cards the games difficulty can be scaled for the level of the players (young or adult). Players are able to cast threats (e.g. fire, pollution, feral animals) that will knock out susceptible animals in play from the game. Players also have the ability to purchase protections from these threats before they come out.

From the publisher's website:
In large steps we go to the 500th Anniversary of the Reformation. Looking at this great event, we present the new game "Abenteuer Luther".
How was the life of Martin Luther in 1521 and 1522, when he was hiding at the Wartburg translated the New Testament? He had to deal with what problems? The difficulties he had to contend with? What has frustrated him what made â€‹â€‹him happy? Answers to all these questions and more, the new social game "Abenteuer Luther". Besides, the players learn more about Martin Luther resume his career and his family.

In "Abenteuer Luther," players fight as Martin Luther in his hiding at the Wartburg through the day. Whether a fire sets the battlements of the castle on fire or be taken from a paper mill new paper has thus Luther's translation of "The New Testament" falters - in a playful way, players learn how difficult life was for Luther in the castle.

A fun board game for 2-6 players from 8 years with lots of accessories:
almost 200 playing cards consisting of 70 materials, 40-event, 50-question, 30 action cards 6 points tables, 6 different colored game pieces of wood, one throws, 1 game board, 1Spielanleitung

Here's a little insight into Luther's game:
The aim of the game is to collect as many points with material cards, because who has the most points at the end is the winner. The game ends when all cards are used up material from the pile on the board.

Exciting the game is through the 3 different colored fields:
Blue fields are event fields.
This means something happens, such as: you panic when they tell you, an Imperial spy who sneaked into the castle. If that's true, you're nowhere safe anymore ...

Red fields are fields of action.
Here it is important to think carefully: I Swap my material cards that are divided into everyday undFesttagskarten and for which many different points there, with the cards of my teammates? Or should I keep my action card for a lot of light for later play on?

Green fields are question cards.
Here the player can score points with correct answers and gather material cards.

An exciting board game with lots of accessories, suitable for families, youth camps, schools, youth group ... A game for 2-6 players aged 8 years.

A Fanmade boardgame, based on the Wing Commander video game from 1993, Privateer: The Kilrathi Menace is a player-driven adventure.

Key Features:
-Challenging Solo and Multiplayer
-Emphasis on Replayability
-Dynamic Universe population
-Dynamic Universe behaviour
-Exploration and other variants
-Multiple quadrants to play in
-Meaningful advancement in multiple factions

Gameplay:
Players travel from location to location, trading goods, taking on missions and catering to powerful factions.  Players can purchase and upgrade new ships and weapons to help them in their goals, all the while being hunted by Military or Pirate factions.  With a dynamic reputation, actions players take will effect what planets, ships and equipment they have access to.

Goal:
Accomplishing great deeds, or difficult tasks will gain players Fame points, and Victory Points.  These points will determine the most notorious adventurer in the game, with the most enduring legacy.  The Solo play variants carry a sense of urgency and doom as players seek to save the quadrant, or become infamous before it is run into chaos by the Kilrathi Menace!

In Codename: Oracle, you are an American CIA Psychic Operative or a Soviet KGB Mentalist in a struggle of wills with the fate of the world at stake. Can you pry the launch codes out of your target's mind before a nuclear showdown?

Each player has a "Mind-field" made up of a 4x5 grid of Zener cards. (Zener cards were designed by perceptual psychologist Karl Zener in the early 1930s and used to conduct experiments for extra-sensory perception, most often clairvoyance.) The players also have a "Code Row" of five cards which represents their launch code. Players must position and remember where cards are in their mind-field in order to group them and perform a "strike", "shield", or "focus". Each of these has a different effect depending on the matching Zener cards turned over and used.

To win the game, a player must either correctly guess each Zener card in the opponent's Code Row, or deal enough psychic damage to the opponent to move that player's life counter to zero.

In Rallye Photo, players split into two teams – each with the same list of items – and they race through the city streets trying to photograph those items as quickly as they can. A flag, a helmet, a car parked on the sidewalk – whichever team has found the most objects after twenty minutes wins!

In addition to more than two dozen cards focusing on items found in cities, the game includes a half-dozen cards for the countryside, beach and mountains. (Cameras not included.)

I've seen a couple of express games and I believe that Mille Bornes is one missing from the lot. So, I've made a really fun twist on the game.

It's a 2-4 player game. Each player begins with a set of 7 Dice. Players roll all their remaining dice each on their turn and select only one die. Following the rules applied to each face, players will give hazards and find remedies to the hazards the other players have given them. Once all dice have been selected, players count their points for the round, take their dice back and another round begins. Once a player achieves exactly 1000 points then that player is the winner.

From the publisher's website:

GRAINVILLE-SUR-ODON, 27 June 1944: The Cameronians expected to find Grainville cleared by 11th Armoured Division. This expectation was confirmed by a squadron of the Fife and Forfars who believed the village was clear of infantry but warned of the possibility of enemy tanks. Fond hopes were rudely shattered at 20:00 hours, as D Company moved into the ruins, supported by two troops of 7th RTR. The place was enemy held, opposition was heavy, and three of the Churchills were quickly knocked out. All through the long summer’s evening, the battle raged to and fro over the ruins of the small town. Finally, the Cameronians and their supporting armour pulled back for the night, and shortly after so did the Germans. At midnight, the Cameronians’ M.O. and Padre ventured into the rubble to search for their wounded and found Grainville deserted. The Cameronians would be back.

Raise your hand ... or optionally SHOUT to your mates for a Projecter Infantry Anti Tank (aka "PIAT) ... if you like the idea of a SIX FOOT LONG historical map with campaign game and macro scenario to play on it. Oops, that pretty much means you're shouting at the top of your lungs for a copy of ATS OMAHA or BERLIN from CH ... we just can't get past the desire to provide you the longest, largest tactical-level battlefields this side of joining a pile of geomorphs at a convention (may we suggest the new Museumfest in Michigan). If you wanted to know if the new British in Normandy releases, i.e., the new editions of the maps ... connect, the answer is "yes". If you wanted to know if these new editions, unlike their predecessors, total about 6' in length ... again, check. Affirmative. Yes. If you want to know what it feels like to collect your Panzerkampfwagen Vg platoon around a hamlet ... and stare over a klick away in game distance .... and order your cardboard Frundsbergers ... panzer marsch! You'll need to mount up and take to the turret in the form of a copy of SHOUT FOR PIATS ... and ORDERS FOR THE MAJOR.

Of course if you want to know what it's like to order your Firefly troop (complete with AFVs bearing a troop leader pennant, see the sample directly above) ... to stop the jerries from going anywhere, let alone forward ... we suggest OFM and SFP ... on the double! Either way, you'll note the road signage says 'this way to Hill 112' and 'this way to Villers Bocage' ... both places that are in hand and coming from CH to build an unprecedented British in Nornandy collection of tactical-level modules ... start engines!

Play the 3 game challenges then win the right to be the Supreme Warrior of all!

Object of the game is to collect two each of pizza and weapons tokens, and then reach the finish space to get your designated "bad guy". Each player starts as either Michelangelo, Donatello, Raphael or Leonardo, and chooses the matching Battle Card. Each Battle Card has two spaces each for pizza and weapons tokens, and a designated bad guy.

The bad guys actually are just decoration, as they all wait together in the "hideout", which is part of the finish space. Game play proceeds with each player spinning the spinner, advancing to the next space on single, linear path from start to finish that has the same color as the one just spun, and collecting either the pizza or weapon token found there.

After playing the 3 games, winning players hold a spin-off to see who be the supreme warrior.

Eternal Dynasty is a game for 2-5 players with elements of territory control, worker placement, and political maneuvering.

Each game consists of a number of Generations equal to the number of players, with each Generation consisting of several rounds of play. At the beginning of each Generation, players will select a Ruler who will have different inherent bonuses for Military or Political Influence, number of cards to play for their Generation, and a unique Ability.

Players take on the role of feuding clans and will fight over control of the 18 provinces of ancient China. As the Generations progress, players will be able to adjust their strategies on the fly or continue reinforcing their current strategies as they change to a new Ruler.

In this game from 1898, players are trying to accumulate 10 buffalo in order to win using a spin-and-move mechanic.

A players turn consists of using the spinner, moving the indicated number of spaces, then completing any actions their space requires.

The spaces are either blank (nothing happens), a buffalo head (the player receives one point), "Captured by Indians" (the player loses a turn), and various spaces moving the player back.

If a player makes it around the board back to "Camp", they start again and go around the board.

The first player to accumulate 10 points and make it back to Camp wins the game.

By the hundreds, creatures are emigrating from the Old World in search of hope and prosperity. The New World offers endless opportunity, but only to those who arrive first. In this clever new game by designer Joe Cannon, players seek out territories to conquer and compete for the most fertile properties, making critical decisions to gain the advantage. This set will provide the basic rules and set you up for future expansions, which will exponentially increase the elements of story and strategy.

Migration is a game suitable for 2-4 players, in which each player takes the role of multiple anthropomorphic animals migrating to a new continent. Players take turns to place an animal token on the board, representing towns. Each new town must originate from the last town placed (with certain exceptions). Each animal token has a unique ability, introducing a high degree of strategy. The game is over when no player is able to make a legal move, and points are scored for each town on the board. The player with the highest score wins.

This entry is for the version of Migration printed by Thegamecrafter.com
IF YOU HAVE THE VERSION OF MIGRATION THAT CAME FROM KICKSTARTER, PLEASE PUT YOUR RATING HERE: https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/158122/migration-book-ii-saga-conflict

Welcome to the dark assembly of the pandemonium! The player is in charge of the political party of the assembly of the pandemonium that try to bribe and assassinate each other. However, the purpose of the game isn't to rule, it's be able to manipulate politics to the best of your ability.

In a 4 player game, players form 2 teams.  The players in the same team sit opposite each other.

There are 3 phases to each round:
Deal each player 6 cards each at the beginning of a round.
1. Drafting phase
 - Everyone drafts 1 card, places it to the side face down, then passes the rest of their hand to the player on their left, continue until you have 6 cards placed face down.  Pick up those cards, those cards now form your hand.
(When playing with 4 players, after the Drafting phase, the players in the same team pass each other 1 card.
2. Play phase
- Everyone selects a card from their hand, and places it face down.  Simultaneously reveal the card chosen.  
If there is a 0, 2, 3, or 7 card revealed the following occurs (starting with the lowest number):
0 Bribe = take a card of the same colour
2 Assassinate = cards that are not the same colour are discarded
3 Spy = On the next turn, the player on your right must show you the card they will play
7 Betray = Take the point card from the player on the right

Everyone plays a card 5 times, and the 6th card is not played.

3. Scoring phase
Add up all the cards that you've won of the same colour.  The player with the most points of a particular colour scores 2 points, and the 2nd player scores (the total points of the player with the most points divided by 5.  e.g. player A scored 16 points from red, player B scored 11 points from red, player C scored 2 points from red.  Player A gets a total of 2 points, player B gets 16/5= 3 points.

Start a new round again by dealing out 4 cards to each player.  Once the cards run out the game is over.  The team which has the most points is the winner.

Hydras is a quick and easy card game with elements of tile laying games and some "take that" mechanics. The game is for 2-4 players, takes about 5 minutes to teach, and around 15-30 minutes to play.

Each player starts with a hydra body card and takes turns playing and drawing cards. Cards can be played on their own hydras to build up their defenses, thwart or undo their opponent's attacks, and increase the number of heads on their hydra. They can also be played to attack your opponent's hydras by cutting off heads or burning stumps.

The game ends when the deck runs out. The player with the most heads at the end of the game wins!

"It is a game with many possibilities. Every gameplay is a new story"

Mesozoic Tales is an indie strategy board game for adults, teenagers, and children (age 12 and up).

Released in 2013, it has been under production for 7 years. It was inspired by books, films and retro videogames from da 1980's and 1990's generations, capturing the essence from many sources that filled the memories of many people through cinema, television, the Nintendo, Sega and PlayStation 1.

A remote island hides a secret: an advanced hi-tech dinosaur zoo. However, the unpredictable happened, and the creatures went loose. The gameplay starts when a group of few people try to put things back in order while the prehistoric beasts roam free.

Due to the incident, buildings on the island went out of energy and the players are found in the middle of the map. From there, they must fight for survival while reactivating the system in the complexes as described in their Mission Cards.

Complexes are activated by using Access Cards, which can be obtained or exchanged at the Access Points on the map.

In case of any assistance, players can carry 3 items in their hands (Action Cards) - vehicles, guns, medical packs, etc. -, that can be obtained at the Maintenance sheds.

It is also possible to play as a dinosaur. Before each turn, players must throw the 'Player Mode' dice to define if he/she will control a carnivorous dinosaur, an herbivore, or a human. In human mode, the player must follow his/her mission normally, but if he/she is playing as a dinosaur, he/she can hunt the opponents down and eat them!

It is a game of many possibilities. Every gameplay is a new story: this makes it terrific fun!

In Wash Out, players are trying to collect cards that depict the clothes hanging on their clothes line. They need to match both color and style.

The game is for 3-6, but the rules say 4 is best. The game is setup with each player sitting in front of a clothesline they wish to use for the game (these are depicted on the board). Then a number of clothespins equal to the number of players, minus 1, is put in the center of the board.

Each turn players will be looking at their hand of five cards, quickly, and passing one of them to the left after playing any that apply to themselves. The rules state this whole process should be done "as rapidly as possible and may be done as noisily as desired."

When a player has the cards that depicts their clothesline, they quietly remove a clothespin from the center. Then all other players may do so.

This is repeated 5 times and end scoring determines the winner. Scoring is based on clothespins and number of cards completing their clothesline.

Trapped is a 3-5 player party game in which you force your friends to perform ridiculous feats for your own amusement. Each time a player fails one of their challenges or is trapped they must draw a card from the Punishment Pile.

Make your best buddy speak like a pirate. Dare your brother to dance like a robot. And try your hardest not to laugh because you could be next. No one is safe while playing the funniest game in the world - TRAPPED.

Table Top Championship Golf is as close to real golf as you can get with dice and paper. Using a grid matrix system, each Championship golf mat has over 550 possible landing locations for your ball. Never before in a golf board game has the player been able to use so much of the hole. Coupled with a wind modifier, frustratingly placed hazards and plenty of trees this game is bound to bring you just as much joy, and sometimes frustration, as the real thing.

Play by yourself just to pass the time, or play with some friends. TTCG can be played with a full foresome and has many different game modes such as Stroke Play, Skins, Scramble, Best Ball, Fourball and more. Have your own favorite method of play? Play it! Want to make up a new game type? Give it a shot.

With 32 hole options, there are 471,435,600 possible course combinations to choose from. Have a favorite hole? Play it more than once. Don't have time for 18? Play a quick game of 9 hole.

We've included 18 scorecards with the game, if you run out, we've provided a link on this page to print out more.

The game Glass Road commemorates the 700-year-old tradition of glass-making in the Bavarian Forest. (Today, the "Glass Road" is a route through the Bavarian forest that takes visitors to many of the old glass houses and museums of that region.) You must skillfully manage your glass and brick production in order to build the right structures that help you keep your business flowing. Cut the forest to keep the fires burning in the ovens, and spread and remove ponds, pits, and groves to supply yourself with the items you need. Fifteen specialists are there at your side to carry out your orders...

In more detail, the game consists of four building periods. Each player has an identical set of fifteen specialist cards, and each specialist comes with two abilities. At the beginning of each building period, you choose a hand of five specialists. If during this building period, you play a specialist that no other player has in hand, you may use both abilities on that card; if two or more players play the same specialist, each of them may use only one of the two abilities. Exploiting the abilities of these specialists lets you collect resources, lay out new landscape tiles (e.g., ponds and pits), and build a variety of buildings, which come in three types:


    Processing buildings
    "Immediate" buildings with a one-time effect 
    Buildings that provide bonus points at the end of the game for various accomplishments


Mastering the balance of knowing the best specialist card to play and being flexible about when you play it — together with assembling a clever combination of buildings — is the key to this game.

The 2021 edition of Glass Road includes previously released promotional material: the Oktoberfest and Adventskalender tiles and the Harlekin card for use in the solitaire version of the game.

From the back of the box:

"What do Aaron Offspeed, Henry Pickoff, Rocky Start, and the Washington Watergates have in common?  They are all part of a unique game called Wanna Buy a Baseball Team Cheap?!

"You are the owner of a baseball team.  Your goal as owner is to be the first person to buy a complete baseball team at the lowest possible price before any other owner.

"Owners may bid, buy, or trade players.  Owners who buy players pay only the stated price.  However when players are traded or bid on any price is possible.

"Owners are able to stay in the game provided they have money.  They may trade in players to the Profit League bank to get much needed cash.

"A player wins by having the most + points at the end of the game provided no other player has completely purchased a baseball team.  Plus points are given for money left at the end of the game.  Minus points are given for each player not purchased during the game.

"Wanna Buy a Baseball Team, Cheap?! is not a boring game.  It gives the participants plenty of action and decision making."

Self-published by the proprietor of M. Foner's Games Only Emporium in Lemoyne, PA, and distributed through the store.  Game seems to be intended to teach mathematics as much as provide a baseball game.  A basketball game also exists, Wanna Buy a Basketball Team Cheap?  No indication of when the game was originally published exists; some of the art strongly suggests the 1970s, although some parts were apparently printed later, in extant copies.

The EPF needs you! Use EPF Agents to solve Field-Ops and earn medals. The first agent to collect 5 Field-Op medals wins. Good luck!

Basic gameplay:
All Field-Ops are shuffled, and the top card of this Field-Op deck is put in the centre of the table. All other cards are shuffled too, and every player gets 5 cards from this Agent Deck. With the youngest player starting, every player now tries to fulfill (one of) the requirement(s) on the Field-Op card to claim it for one or more medals. If not possible, that player draws a card from the Agent Deck, and tries again. If again not possible, it becomes next player's turn. If possible, then you put the Field-Op in question in front of you, discard all cards used to fulfill the requirement in question, put the next Field-Op from the Field-Op Deck into play and draw back up to 5 cards from the Agent Deck. Play continues until one player has accumulated a total of 5+ Field-Op medals.

Box contents:
55 cards (36 normal penguin agent cards, 10 Field-Op mission cards, 9 other agent cards)
1 code card (to unlock items in Club Penguin)
1 rules booklet

Many games are EPIC and take place in a massive world, we wanted to make a game that takes place in a petri dish with minuscule armies battling for dominance.

An exciting tabletop strategy game for 2 to 8 players, where each competes to form the longest chain of NanoBots. There are 8 types of NanoBots, each with its own special ability.

Players take turns playing their NanoBots and cards to build their chain or disrupt others’ until someone runs out of NanoBots. Be careful to watch your bots, you don’t want to play your last one without the longest chain in your grasp.

A Dragon Quest themed strategy game.

Each player controls a roster of monsters with different movement styles akin to chess. The player to successfully invade their opponents castle wins. 
Players roll a six sided die to see how many moves they get on their turn. They may add more moves by spending coins.

The game and rules are entirely japanese, but the full-color rulebook is full of diagrams, illustrations and amusing comics.

A trick taking card game with a twist. Players use a dynamic bidding round to determine trump then play their hands following the standard rules for a trick taking card game. There are 4 suits and 6 dual suits to throw in some havoc.

Young children's game where sounds are played on a tape cassette. Each child has an equal number of cards and when they hear a sound they think belongs to one of their cards they can announce it and lose the card. First to lose all their cards, wins.

Kronocell is a two-player skirmish miniatures game that combines strategy, bluffing and positional play. With time being a main component, combat doesn't rely on dice rolls, large decks of cards or complicated rules. Featuring an elegant Action/Reaction mechanic, Turns are shared between players, creating a fluid action experience.

By strategically maneuvering your Units and using Command Cards you will lay waste to your opponent, attacking and countering his moves, while at the same time gaining control over vital Control Points scattered around the Battlefield.

Kronocell is geared towards war and strategy gamers that enjoy deep, while easy and fluid gameplay. Unit stats feature only Movement and Health Points, but the underlying Action System allows for a highly diverse and unique gameplay of each Unit.

Players travel via ships toward former Dutch trading colonies.

The title of the game is a play on Arnold Weruméus Buning's book "Met de Rotterdamsche Lloyd naar Egypte, Ceylon, Sumatra en Java."

In the U.S. wild west, the eternal battle between the law and the outlaws keeps heating up. Suddenly, a rain of arrows darken the sky: It's an Indian attack! Are you bold enough to keep up with the Indians? Do you have the courage to challenge your fate? Can you expose and defeat the ruthless gunmen around you?

BANG! The Dice Game keeps the core of the Bang! card game in place. At the start of the game, players each take a role card that secretly places them on a team: the Sheriff and deputies, outlaws, and renegades. The Sheriff and deputies need to kill the outlaws, the outlaws win by killing the Sheriff, and the renegades want to be the last players alive in the game.

Each player also receives a character card which grants him a special power in the game. The Sheriff reveals his role card and takes the first turn of the game. On a turn, a player can roll the five dice up to three times, using the results of the dice to shoot neighboring players, increase the range of his shots, heal his (or anyone else's) life points, or put him in range of the Indians, which are represented by nine tokens in the center of the table. Each time a player rolls an arrow, he takes one of these tokens; when the final token is taken, each player loses one life point for each token he holds, then the tokens are returned to the center of the table.

If a player collects a trio of Gatling symbols on the dice, he fires one shot at everyone else and rids himself of Indian tokens. Who'll get his shot off first? Play continues until one team meets its winning condition – and death won't necessarily keep you from winning as long as your teammates pull through!

"North Korea invaded the Republic of South Korea in 1950.  The UN voted to recommend military assistance to the Republic of South Korea, and President Truman sent US troops to Korea.  The North captured much of the Korean Peninsula and the only hold outs were in the Pusan Perimeter.  General MaCarthur proposed relieving the pressure on Pusan with a surprise amphibious landing behind enemy lines at Inchon.  The landing was a  major victory for the UN forces in Korea.  UN forces went on the offensive and drove north until the Chinese intervened.  The war ended in an armistice, with a demilitarized zone separating the two Koreas near  the 38th parallel.  The border remains an area of heightened tensions to this day.  The Korean War is sometimes called the "forgotten war" in the United States because it comes between two more famous conflicts, WWII and the Vietnam War."

A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules.

Forces portrayed in the game include American squads in units of 8 soldiers, with an officer, radioman and two BAR machine gunners for each squad and North Korean squads in units of 15 and have one officer and one machine gun.

2WW: The War in Europe is a grand-strategic game utilizing armies or army groups, air forces, and fleets. The game covers the entire conflict in Europe, North Africa, and the Middle East. There are two players or sides in the game. The Axis controls Germany, Italy, and all friendly minor countries. The Allied player controls France, Great Britain, the  Soviet Union, and the United States when it enters the conflict.

Small in size, big in scope, 2WW: The War in Europe is playable in an evening, yet has enough depth to satisfy most grognards. From the war in the desert, to the battle in the Atlantic, it's all here.

The battles of World War I completely and forever redefined warfare in the western world. They marked the end of the older tradition and the beginning of the age of total war, and a century of conflict.

Miracle on the Marne is an operational level game of the Battle of the Marne that occurred near Paris, France in September, 1914. This battle changed the course of the war and had either side been able to achieve a decisive victory, the horrors of the following four years of trench warfare might have never occurred. In the game, one player or team of players, will control the Allies (France and Britain), while the opposing player or team will control the Central Powers (Germany).

Each hex on the game map represents approximately fi fteen to twenty miles. Units represent brigades and divisions.
- 1 Game Map
- 2 Charts and Tables Sheets
- 2 Counter Sheets
- Rules Booklet

(source: One small step website)

Collect your carrots - but watch out for the farmer.

Players take turns rolling dice to move their bunnies up a path.  Upon reaching the end of the path each bunny rolls a different die to determine how many carrots they can look at.  If the carrot they pull from the board matches their color they keep it.  Upon getting three carrots the player wins.  However if the farmer is rolled then the player sends an opponent's bunny back to the start of the path.

Card game from the American Civil War period. The cards feature famous authors and quotes associated with them. Instead of colleciting sets like a regular game of Authors, in this game cards are played to the table domino-fashion (Quote - Author - Quote - Author and so on). The first player to use all their cards, wins.

Nice looking target game. Take turns to fire the gun and shoot the Dwarfs. The ones you knock down score you points;
Sneezy 10
Happy 20
Doc 30
Bashful 40
Sleepy 50
Grumpy 60
Dopey 70
When you finish the game, the one with the most points, wins.

From the Tinderbox Games website:

A new way to play with words!  SCRABBLE® Cards offers three different games in one deluxe package.
Play Classic, Forfeit, or try new SCRABBLE® Rummy for a new twist on an old favourite.

Contents:
136 cards
Card tray
Rules for all 3 games

From the website of Madison Game, a retailer:

Three fun ways to play the world's favourite word game in a handy and portable format.

SCRABBLE Cards Classic
Make the best word you can from the cards you are dealt. Double and Triple Word cards add to your score, as all players race to hold the highest total.

SCRABBLE Cards Forfeit
Now you each have an Action Card which you can play at any time; either to increase your score... or take points away from another player.

SCRABBLE Cards Rummy
Gives you a different word target in each of ten rounds. Make the best words you can to fit, but be quick or you'll miss out on the points.

In the near future our planet has been devastated by a global war, which ended with the modern amenities and technology. Only a few ill-equipped factories, decimated armies and insufficient resources have been in the hands of four groups scattered over the face of the Earth. You lead one of them.

N*Go is a strategy game board where you must become the protector of the planet's resources for the survival of your people.

Starting from a situation where all forces and resources are in balance, luck has no place here. There is no win card or dice that do the work for you, every attack has a possible defense and nobody knows the strategy of the opponents.

The rules are easy and simple, all goals are in sight of achieving these objectives... heck you have to be prepared if you want to get it!

Make alliances, colonizes virally, passively awaiting development of the strategy of your opponents ... or a mixture of all this. There is no right or wrong way of doing things here, you have nothing to lose, yet is all at stake.

A group of students from the University of Texas has decided to go for a field trip to an abandoned military base, lost in the middle of the desert, but once they arrive, nothing happens as expected. Indeed, the old base has become a laboratory for a Mexican drug cartel, exploiting at will a cheap and dutiful workforce: zombies! And this doesn't count the other strange creatures that have lost themselves in this forsaken place...

In Texas Zombies, each player is secretly a member of one of two teams: Beta Lambda and Darwin & Dragons. During the game, each player must face a variety of situations — either dangerous, terrifying or simply unlikely — and try to overcome them using only the random items he has on hand. The active player tells a story using 1-3 of the item cards he has in hand, then everyone else votes on whether or not he survives. If he does, he keeps the threat card, and whichever team has collected the most threats at game end wins.
A Robot dice combat game with 2 leveling cards(Hit, Power), also a Combo card. Remove your opponents Life points to be the last PowerBot standing.

In the Dutch game of 'Tuintopia' you will be building a garden.

The game is a strategic game in which you and your opponents build together on the same garden, trying to score as many points as you can.

You will score points by making connections, i.e. a waterpump delivers water to a vegetable garden (which needs water to grow the vegetables) and then you gain one point.

RoShamBo Rush is a competitive racing game. No story here. Just tighten your shoes, race, and be prepared for a nail biting finish. RoShamBo Rush was designed to be quick paced and to keep all players in the game with its system of catch-up logic. There is a very small learning curve, making it a great game to introduce newcomers to table top gaming.

As the name implies, Rock-Paper-Scissors is a large part of the game. Players duel each other using a set of cards that remain in each players possession throughout the game. Banter is encouraged. It is a good way to solicit a tell from your opponents. If you have people reading skills, they do come in handy.

The game features racers (pawns) that stand over 2" tall. The racers are adorned with helmets and body armor when a player lands on a "Armor Up" space. Armor serves as insurance for losing a battle and keeps that racer from taking hit points in exchange for a piece of armor.

Though linear like a race course, you have decisions to make on your turn. Who will you battle? When is the best time to play your Twist Cards? Nobody coasts to an easy victory here. Only the scrappiest competitors will earn a place on the winners podium which only has limited space reserved for the top three racers.

From website:

Board your safari truck for an adventure through Southern Africa to save Africa’s Big Five animals!

As a conservationist working in Southern Africa, you’ll travel to five major Reserves, sighting and researching famous wild animals known as the Big Five: the rhino, leopard, lion, elephant and buffalo.

Translation: The Wolf and the Seven Young Kids
players(kids) win if two of them reach target space; wolf wins after 6 kids are caught; with less players than 8 all seven kids are divided;

A 'Roll & Move' game; being a little goat throw the die and move forward, wolf only is throwing 2 dice; follow instructions glued into the lid ending on a marked space.

Game should had been published late 1920's/early 30's

As the battle of Chancellorsville raged, a Union corps was dispatched to hit the vulnerable Confederate army from behind. The flanking column was delayed by a single Confederate brigade at Salem Church. The battle grew as Confederate arrived first to firm up the front, then to turn the tables on the Federals. The flankers became flanked, then had to fight for their lives.

Game Contents:

•    11 x 17” map
•    40 die-cut counters
•    Scenario Instructions
•    Four page rule booklet

Scale:
•    Level: Brigade
•    Hex:  352 yards
